title: China donates RMB 4 million worth of furniture to Sudan Friendship Hall
description: On May 24, 2010, the Chinese ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen and the Director of the Sudan Friendship Department Mahajib Ibrahim signed the handover certificate for the furniture renewal project of the Friendship Hall in Sudan on behalf of their respective governments (援苏丹友谊厅家具更新项目). RMB 4 million worth of furniture was donated to the Sudan Friendship Hall.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates RMB 4 million worth of furniture to Sudan Friendship Hall

# Description
On May 24, 2010, the Chinese ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen and the Director of the Sudan Friendship Department Mahajib Ibrahim signed the handover certificate for the furniture renewal project of the Friendship Hall in Sudan on behalf of their respective governments (援苏丹友谊厅家具更新项目). RMB 4 million worth of furniture was donated to the Sudan Friendship Hall.
justification: Project involves donation of furniture to a government facility with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Furniture donation to Sudan Friendship Hall, no energy or industrial components mentioned

title: Chinese government assists Sudan to construct 30 wells in Darfur (linked to #47218)
description: On July 7, 2010, Ambassador Li Chengwen signed and submitted to the Sudan side for the exchange of documents for the 30 well projects in Darfur, Sudan (援苏丹达尔富尔地区30口水井项目). On July 13, 2010, Tejani Saleh, Minister of International Cooperation of Sudan, signed a replies to confirm the communication. On October 11, 2010 Sudanese Humanitarian Aid Commissioner signed a contract with Tianjin Huabei Nonferrous Construction Engineering Company to dig the wells. The value of the wells is unknown.  In 2008, the Chinese government also drilled 10 water wells for the Darfur region of Sudan. By the end of November in 2008, the construction of these 10 wells were completed (captured in #47218).
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Chinese government assists Sudan to construct 30 wells in Darfur (linked to #47218)

# Description
On July 7, 2010, Ambassador Li Chengwen signed and submitted to the Sudan side for the exchange of documents for the 30 well projects in Darfur, Sudan (援苏丹达尔富尔地区30口水井项目). On July 13, 2010, Tejani Saleh, Minister of International Cooperation of Sudan, signed a replies to confirm the communication. On October 11, 2010 Sudanese Humanitarian Aid Commissioner signed a contract with Tianjin Huabei Nonferrous Construction Engineering Company to dig the wells. The value of the wells is unknown.  In 2008, the Chinese government also drilled 10 water wells for the Darfur region of Sudan. By the end of November in 2008, the construction of these 10 wells were completed (captured in #47218).
justification: Project focuses on water supply infrastructure for humanitarian purposes without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 30 wells in Darfur region, water supply and sanitation sector, humanitarian aid context

title: China provides material support for Sudanese elections (linked to #2451)
description: On January 24, 2010, Chinese Ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen signed a pledge that China would donate hundreds of computers, printers, televisions and other office equipment to support the Sudanese national elections in April of that year. On March 26, 2010, the supplies were delivered to Khartoum International Airport. On April 1, Ambassador Li Chengwen and Vice Chairman of the Sudanese National Election Commission Abdullah Ahmed signed a certificate officially handing them over to Sudan. The value of the equipment is unknown.  This project is linked to #2451, a grant of USD 3 million also to assist Sudan's national elections.
combined_text:

GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Description
On January 24, 2010, Chinese Ambassador to Sudan Li Chengwen signed a pledge that China would donate hundreds of computers, printers, televisions and other office equipment to support the Sudanese national elections in April of that year. On March 26, 2010, the supplies were delivered to Khartoum International Airport. On April 1, Ambassador Li Chengwen and Vice Chairman of the Sudanese National Election Commission Abdullah Ahmed signed a certificate officially handing them over to Sudan. The value of the equipment is unknown.  This project is linked to #2451, a grant of USD 3 million also to assist Sudan's national elections.
justification: Project involves donation of election-related equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact

title: China donates two batches of anti-malaria drugs to Sudan in August 2010
description: On August 11, 2010, the Chinese Government donated the second and third batches of anti-malaria drugs to the Government of Sudan. The total cost of the medicine donated and the arrival date of the first batch are unknown.
staff_comments: South Sudan achieved independence in 2011; as this donation took place in 2010, the recipient country is Sudan.

title: China donates sports equipments to Southern Sudan
description: On July 15, 2010, the Chinese government donated a set of sports equipments to the autonomous government of Southern Sudan. The donation includes basketballs, soccer balls and sports clothes. The cost of the donation is unknown.
staff_comments: This project specifies that the donation was given to Autonomous South Sudan; however, South Sudan did not achieve independence until 2011. As a result, Sudan will remain the recipient country at the time of the donation.
combined_text:

OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title

# Description

justification: Project involves donation of sports equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of sports equipment (basketballs, soccer balls, sports clothes) to Southern Sudan

title: China offers training to officials from Southern Sudan
description: On July 22, 2010, the Chinese Consulate in Juba held a reception for over 30 government officials who had received training in China. The officials came from Southern Sudan's Ministry of Health, Ministry of Trade and Industry, Ministry of Energy and Mines, and other government departments. The exact nature of the training and when it occurred is unknown. The beginning of the training is unclear.
staff_comments: The project took place in what would become South Sudan in 2011. However, this training project took place in 2010, before South Sudan received independence from Sudan. As a result, the recipient country is coded as Sudan.
combined_text:

The officials came from Southern Sudan's Ministry of Health, Ministry of Trade and Industry, Ministry of Energy and Mines, and other government departments. The exact nature of the training and when it occurred is unknown. The beginning of the training is unclear.

title: Chinese Embassy in Sudan grants $35,350 USD for First Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital Reconstruction and Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#53415, #30435, #53314, and #71822)
description: In 2009, the Chinese Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) sent its first assessment team to Sudan for the purpose of investigationg the first Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital Reconstruction and Expansion Project. The Chinese Embassy in Sudan granted $35,350 USD for this project.  In May 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) granted $600,000 USD to CFPA for the construction of Abu Ushar Hospital (see Project #53415). The final cost of the project overran this fund, ending with a total cost of $1.105 million USD (RMB 6.93 million). CFPA took on 73 percent of the $505,000 in cost overruns equal to $368,650 USD (see Project #71822); Sudanese Al-Birr and Tawasul Charity Organization (BTO) took 20 percent equal to $101,000 USD; and the remaining $35,350 USD was covered by the Chinese Embassy in Sudan.  Chinese Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) was the implementing contractor. Construction began in June 2010. The increased costs and other difficulties led to the project being completed three months behind schedule. According to the Asian Development source, construction was completed in May 2011 and the hospital was inaugurated on 16 July 2011.  The hospital was originally a horse farm built during the British colonial period in 1929. In 1974, Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital became the headquarters for the Chinese medical mission. The hospital receives 5,000 cases monthly. China Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) carried out a maternal and infant healthcare network project at this facility (see Project ID#30435). Abu Ushar Hospital was renovated again in 2016 (see Project ID#53314).
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援苏阿布欧舍医院改扩建项目 or 苏阿布欧舍医院改扩建项目 or 援苏丹阿布欧舍医院改扩建项目 or 苏丹医院项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Sudan grants $35,350 USD for First Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital Reconstruction and Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#53415, #30435, #53314, and #71822)

# Description
In 2009, the Chinese Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) sent its first assessment team to Sudan for the purpose of investigationg the first Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital Reconstruction and Expansion Project. The Chinese Embassy in Sudan granted $35,350 USD for this project.  In May 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) granted $600,000 USD to CFPA for the construction of Abu Ushar Hospital (see Project #53415). The final cost of the project overran this fund, ending with a total cost of $1.105 million USD (RMB 6.93 million). CFPA took on 73 percent of the $505,000 in cost overruns equal to $368,650 USD (see Project #71822); Sudanese Al-Birr and Tawasul Charity Organization (BTO) took 20 percent equal to $101,000 USD; and the remaining $35,350 USD was covered by the Chinese Embassy in Sudan.  Chinese Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) was the implementing contractor. Construction began in June 2010. The increased costs and other difficulties led to the project being completed three months behind schedule. According to the Asian Development source, construction was completed in May 2011 and the hospital was inaugurated on 16 July 2011.  The hospital was originally a horse farm built during the British colonial period in 1929. In 1974, Abu Ushar Friendship Hospital became the headquarters for the Chinese medical mission. The hospital receives 5,000 cases monthly. China Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) carried out a maternal and infant healthcare network project at this facility (see Project ID#30435). Abu Ushar Hospital was renovated again in 2016 (see Project ID#53314).
justification: Project focuses on hospital reconstruction and expansion, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Hospital reconstruction and expansion project, healthcare facility improvement, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Ministry of Culture Donates Musical Instruments to Syria
description: On August 30, 2010, the Chinese Ministry of Culture completed the handover of musical instruments and supplies to the Syrian Ministry of Culture. Chinese ambassador Li and Syrian Cultural Minister Riad signed the transfer certificate on behalf of both parties. Li Jingfang, cultural counselor of the embassy, ​​attended the handover ceremony.
staff_comments: This project has been coded as Development intent, because it does not seem to be promoting Chinese culture but instead supporting the Syrian Ministry of Culture.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Culture Donates Musical Instruments to Syria

# Description
On August 30, 2010, the Chinese Ministry of Culture completed the handover of musical instruments and supplies to the Syrian Ministry of Culture. Chinese ambassador Li and Syrian Cultural Minister Riad signed the transfer certificate on behalf of both parties. Li Jingfang, cultural counselor of the embassy, ​​attended the handover ceremony.
justification: Project involves cultural donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of musical instruments and supplies, cultural exchange focus

title: CPFHK provides loan for acquisition of 35% ownership stake in Syria Shell Petroleum Development from Shell
description: On February 22, 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) concluded a share purchase agreement with Shell in which CNPC agreed to acquire a 35 percent ownership stake in Syria Shell Petroleum Development (SSPD), a unit of Royal Dutch Shell, for $1.6 billion. At the time, SSPD had interests in three production licenses -- Deir-Ez-Zor, Fourth Annex and Ash Sham -- that are operated by the Al Furat Petroleum Company (AFPC), in which Shell had a 31.25 percent ownership stake. CNPC Finance (HK) Limited (CPFHK) issue a loan to CNPC to facilitate the acquisition. Then, in May 2010, the acquisition was completed. In December 2011, in compliance with international sanctions on Syria, including European Council Decision 2011/782/CFSP, Shell suspended all exploration and production activities in Syria.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Euphrates Project. The Chinese project title is 中东地区叙利亚幼发拉底项目 or 敘利亞幼發拉底項目. 2. CNPC Finance (HK) Limited is identified by official sources as the financier of the acquisition. AidData assumes for the time being that the face value of the acquisition (overseas investment) loan  (境外投资项目案例) from CPFHK was worth approximately 75% of the the total cost of the acquisition ($1.2 billion or 75% of $1.6 billion). This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
CPFHK provides loan for acquisition of 35% ownership stake in Syria Shell Petroleum Development from Shell

# Description
On February 22, 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) concluded a share purchase agreement with Shell in which CNPC agreed to acquire a 35 percent ownership stake in Syria Shell Petroleum Development (SSPD), a unit of Royal Dutch Shell, for $1.6 billion. At the time, SSPD had interests in three production licenses -- Deir-Ez-Zor, Fourth Annex and Ash Sham -- that are operated by the Al Furat Petroleum Company (AFPC), in which Shell had a 31.25 percent ownership stake. CNPC Finance (HK) Limited (CPFHK) issue a loan to CNPC to facilitate the acquisition. Then, in May 2010, the acquisition was completed. In December 2011, in compliance with international sanctions on Syria, including European Council Decision 2011/782/CFSP, Shell suspended all exploration and production activities in Syria.
justification: Acquisition of ownership stake in oil production company focused on petroleum development
evidence: Ownership stake in Syria Shell Petroleum Development, interests in oil production licenses, petroleum development focus

title: CDB provides $20 million loan to National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) for on-lending purposes in 2010 (Linked to Project ID#91981)
description: In September 2006, the National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) and the Xinjiang Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $10 million loan (currency swap) agreement. CDB had ‘upsized’ the loan to $25 million by December 2008. These borrowings (captured via Project ID#91981) reportedly carried a 4-year maturity (final maturity date: September 2010) and an annual interest rate of 2.5%. The borrower (NBT) used the proceeds of the loan to on-lend to a select group of commercial banks for agricultural development activities at interest rates of 4%, 6%, or 14%.   Then, in September 2010, NBT and CDB signed a signed a $20 million loan (currency swap) agreement (captured via Project ID#91982). This loan reportedly carried a 2.5% interest rate, an 11-year maturity (final maturity date: September 15, 2021), and a 5-year grace period. However, the borrower made its first principal repayment ahead of schedule on March 15, 2012. Its next principal repayment was scheduled for March 15, 2014 and thereafter the loan was repayable in equal semi-annual amounts until September 15, 2021. The annual financial statements of NBT provide evidence that repayments were made between 2014 and 2021.
staff_comments: 1. Multiple sources indicate that the September 2006 and September 2010 agreements between NBT and CDB were currency swap arrangements. A typical bilateral currency swap (BCS) agreement — also known as a central bank liquidity swap agreement — is an agreement between the central banks of two countries to exchange cash flows in different currencies at predetermined rates over a specified period of time. Central banks participate in these agreements to facilitate bilateral trade settlements using their national currencies (rather than relying upon on a third-party currency such as the U.S. dollar), manage demands from their local banks, and provide liquidity support to financial markets. The party that draws down on the swap line becomes the borrower and the other party becomes lender. During the term of the swap, the party that draws down on the swap line makes either fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amount. If both parties draw down on the swap line, then both parties exchange fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amounts. The 5-step process of drawing upon a currency swap line with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) can described from the perspective of an importer in a given country (‘Country X’) seeking to settle trade with a Chinese firm in RMB. Step 1: The central bank of Country X and the PBOC activate their currency swap in advance, at which point each party deposits a specific amount of its currency in an account controlled by the other party (i.e. the central bank of Country X deposits local currency in an account controlled by the PBOC, and the PBOC deposits an equivalent amount in RMB in an account controlled by the central bank of Country X). Step 2: A firm in Country X that imports goods from China applies for an RMB-denominated loan from a domestic bank. Step 3: The domestic bank in Country X that receives the loan application then applies to its central bank for an RMB-denominated loan. After a review process, the central bank of Country X notifies the domestic bank applicant that its loan application was approved. The central bank of Country X subsequently requests that the PBOC transfer RMB funds from the central bank of Country X’s swap account within the PBOC to the loan applicant’s account with a corresponding bank in China. Step 4: The domestic bank in Country X directs the corresponding bank in China to transfer RMB funds into a Chinese exporter’s account, and the corresponding bank in China provides RMB funds to the Chinese exporter. Step 5: The importer in Country X repays the RMB-denominated loan at its maturity date. The domestic bank notifies the central bank of Country X of the repayment, and transfers RMB into the central bank’s account within the PBOC through the corresponding bank in China. For the central bank of Country X, the RMB deposit is an asset that should be recorded on its balance sheet as an official reserve asset denominated in RMB. The contra entry of this asset is the liability in the local currency of Country X that represents China’s claims in the central bank of Country X. This should be also recorded on the balance sheet of the central bank of Country X. At the time of the exchange of currencies, it should be recorded as an increase in assets and an increase in liabilities of the monetary authorities in the balance of payments. The reason why the PBOC uses this mechanism to provide renminbi liquidity to other central bank is to increase the speed, convenience, and volume of transactions between the two countries. More detailed information about currency swaps with the PBOC can be found at https://www.imf.org/-/media/Files/Publications/WP/2021/English/wpiea2021210-print-pdf.ashx and https://thechinaguys.com/the-rise-of-the-renminbi-the-reality-of-bilateral-swap-agreements/ and https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/bop/2017/pdf/17-25a.pdf. 2. AidData treats drawdowns under BCS agreements as collateralized loans because, in a BCS arrangement, the currency of the borrower is held as collateral while the lender receives interest on the amount drawn down by the borrower until repayment is made. 33. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦国民银行货币互换项目. 4. The IMF claims that NBT’s borrowings from the CDB ‘were priced at 2.5 to 5 percent.’ This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
CDB provides $20 million loan to National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) for on-lending purposes in 2010 (Linked to Project ID#91981)

# Description
In September 2006, the National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) and the Xinjiang Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $10 million loan (currency swap) agreement. CDB had ‘upsized’ the loan to $25 million by December 2008. These borrowings (captured via Project ID#91981) reportedly carried a 4-year maturity (final maturity date: September 2010) and an annual interest rate of 2.5%. The borrower (NBT) used the proceeds of the loan to on-lend to a select group of commercial banks for agricultural development activities at interest rates of 4%, 6%, or 14%.   Then, in September 2010, NBT and CDB signed a signed a $20 million loan (currency swap) agreement (captured via Project ID#91982). This loan reportedly carried a 2.5% interest rate, an 11-year maturity (final maturity date: September 15, 2021), and a 5-year grace period. However, the borrower made its first principal repayment ahead of schedule on March 15, 2012. Its next principal repayment was scheduled for March 15, 2014 and thereafter the loan was repayable in equal semi-annual amounts until September 15, 2021. The annual financial statements of NBT provide evidence that repayments were made between 2014 and 2021.
justification: Project involves financial services and lending activities without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan agreement between banks for on-lending purposes, no specific environmental or energy-related activities mentioned
